TITLE: Chinese Banking Scandal Tests Faith in Communist Party’s Leadership
SUMMARY: The disappearance of ordinary savers’ money, and the government’s seemingly indifferent response, could pose a major test for the Communist Party’s legitimacy.

TITLE: Hey, Is Anybody Watching the Interns?
SUMMARY: School is out for the summer — but in some cases, so are the bosses.

TITLE: Word of Trump Media Deal Is Said to Have Leaked Months in Advance
SUMMARY: Federal authorities are investigating a surge in trading that preceded the announcement of a $300 million deal with the former president’s media company.

TITLE: Private Mars Landing Mission Aims to Beat SpaceX
SUMMARY: Relativity Space, which could launch its first rocket soon, and Impulse Space, founded by a SpaceX veteran, optimistically say that together they can reach the red planet a few years from now.

TITLE: How Joe Manchin Left a Global Tax Deal in Limbo
SUMMARY: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen’s signature achievement is in jeopardy if the United States cannot ratify the tax agreement that she brokered.

TITLE: As Baby Boomers Age, Developers Explore Housing Options for Them
SUMMARY: Shifting demographics are reshaping complexes built for older Americans, who are looking for a variety of rates and services.

TITLE: Elon Musk and Twitter to Go to Trial Over Deal In October
SUMMARY: Twitter had sought to expedite the case by requesting a trial in September, which Mr. Musk had countered by asking for a trial in February.

TITLE: Netflix Is Set to Announce Earnings
SUMMARY: The streaming giant, facing significant headwinds, has said it expected to lose two million subscribers in the second quarter.

TITLE: Fund Managers Show ‘Dire’ Levels of Pessimism, Poll Finds
SUMMARY: Investors surveyed by Bank of America have never been more pessimistic about the economic outlook.

TITLE: Amazon Sues More Than 10,000 Facebook Groups Over Fake Reviews
SUMMARY: The e-commerce site said the groups targeted its sites in the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Spain and Japan.

TITLE: The Cost of Extreme Heat
SUMMARY: Britain this morning recorded its highest temperature ever, bringing parts of the country to a standstill and testing infrastructure.

TITLE: France Will Spend Nearly $10 Billion to Renationalize EDF
SUMMARY: The government offered to buy the shares it doesn’t already own in EDF, which operates all of the country’s nuclear plants, in the face of a worsening energy crisis after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Indian Rupee Hits Weakest Level Ever Against U.S. Dollar
SUMMARY: The Indian currency has lost about 7 percent of its value against the dollar this year, a victim of higher energy prices and economic uncertainty.

TITLE: Can a ‘Magic’ Protein Slow the Aging Process?
SUMMARY: Elevian is one of several companies searching for ways to increase life span — in this case, using a protein called GDF11. But challenges lie ahead.

TITLE: The Best Restaurants in Basque Country, Spain, According to a Michelin-Starred Chef
SUMMARY: Álvaro Garrido, the chef of the Michelin-starred Mina restaurant and a Bilbao native, shares five favorite restaurants that exemplify the resilient spirit of Spain’s northern autonomous region.

TITLE: Germany Waits for Russia to Restart the Gas on Nord Stream 1
SUMMARY: A shutdown to perform maintenance on the pipeline, the main artery between Russia and Germany, is expected to end later this week amid heightened tensions.

TITLE: Pulitzer Board Rejects Trump Request to Toss Out Wins for Russia Coverage
SUMMARY: The board said it had found nothing to discredit the entries after reviewing the prize submissions from The New York Times and The Washington Post.

TITLE: What Pregnancy and Childbirth Do to the Bodies of Young Girls
SUMMARY: An Ohio 10-year-old’s recent abortion has generated fierce debate. Doctors in countries where pregnancy is common in adolescents say the toll of childbirth on young bodies is brutal.

TITLE: Uber Agrees to Pay Disabled Riders to Settle Federal Lawsuit
SUMMARY: The Justice Department sued Uber last year for charging fees to passengers who took extra time to get into their vehicles.

TITLE: Takeaways From Banks Second Quarter Earnings
SUMMARY: Wall Street bank executives said consumer spending was up, markets were volatile and they did not think the economy was headed for a recession.

TITLE: Amazon is giving Prime Video a face-lift.
SUMMARY: The company hopes a new interface — replacing a much-maligned predecessor — will make the streaming service easier and more inviting for viewers.

TITLE: Amazon C.E.O. Andy Jassy Breaks From the Bezos Way
SUMMARY: Jeff Bezos’ successor has set himself apart with a hands-on approach in Washington.

TITLE: Netflix Bets Big on ‘The Gray Man’
SUMMARY: The streaming service hopes its latest release can be the start of a blockbuster franchise that attracts much-needed subscribers.

TITLE: Goldman Sachs Beats Rivals as Traders Take Advantage of Volatility
SUMMARY: Despite better-than-expected profit, the Wall Street giant’s leaders said they would slow hiring and review stock repurchases as the economy becomes more “uncertain.”

TITLE: Delta Air Lines Orders 100 Boeing 737 Max Planes
SUMMARY: The purchase reflects confidence that the large version of the aircraft, the Max 10, will win regulatory approval.

TITLE: Uniper, Germany Energy Provider, Runs Through Credit
SUMMARY: One of Germany’s largest energy providers is hoping that Berlin will help keep it afloat as limited gas from Russia and high prices drive its losses into the millions.

TITLE: Mattel to Reintroduce Dormant Brands Major Matt Mason, Big Jim and Pulsar
SUMMARY: The toymaker will reintroduce three toy lines, Major Matt Mason, Big Jim and Pulsar, this week at Comic-Con as part of a strategy to dig deeper into its intellectual property portfolio.

TITLE: The Andy Jassy Way at Amazon
SUMMARY: The longtime lieutenant to Jeff Bezos has made more changes than many expected since becoming C.E.O.

TITLE: 4 Dead in Indiana Mall Shooting, Officials Say
SUMMARY: The attack by a gunman unfolded at the Greenwood Park Mall in Greenwood, Ind., on Sunday before another armed man fatally shot the assailant, city officials said.

TITLE: They Had Miscarriages, and New Abortion Laws Obstructed Treatment
SUMMARY: Surgical procedures and medication for miscarriages are identical to those for abortion, and some patients report delayed or denied miscarriage care because doctors and pharmacists fear running afoul of abortion bans.

TITLE: Global Central Banks Ramp Up Inflation Fight
SUMMARY: Central banks in the U.S., Europe, Canada and parts of Asia are lifting interest rates rapidly as they try to wrestle breakneck inflation under control.

TITLE: Jewelry and Gems Worth Millions Stolen From Brink’s Truck in California
SUMMARY: The value of the missing merchandise, which was headed last week to an International Gem and Jewelry Show event, was unclear. One conservative figure put the value at up to $10 million.

TITLE: The Week in Business: Twitter Hits Back
SUMMARY: Inflation in June was high. The euro tumbled to parity with the U.S. dollar. And central banks around the world are raising interest rates.

TITLE: Passengers Sigh as Heathrow Caps Numbers to Head Off ‘Airmageddon’
SUMMARY: After two years of pandemic-enforced staycations, demand for travel has come roaring back in Europe, and airports are finding it impossible to keep up.

TITLE: Economy Is at Risk of Recession by a Force Hiding in Plain Sight
SUMMARY: Well more than two years into the worst pandemic in a century, the accompanying economic shock continues to assault global fortunes.

TITLE: A Warren Buffett Protégée Strikes Out on Her Own
SUMMARY: Tracy Britt Cool spent a decade working closely with the renowned investor. She is now applying those lessons to her own firm.

TITLE: Getting a Passport Will Be Another Pain for Summer Travels
SUMMARY: If you’re urgently in need of a new or updated passport, brace yourself: Options have narrowed — and it’s likely going to cost you.

TITLE: Nikole Hannah-Jones and Univerity of North Carolina Settle Hiring Dispute
SUMMARY: Ms. Hannah-Jones, who won a Pulitzer Prize for the 1619 Project, had said she was considering legal action against the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

TITLE: Demand for Monkeypox Vaccine Exceeds Supply, C.D.C. Says
SUMMARY: The United States has ordered nearly seven million doses in total, but most of them will not arrive for months.

TITLE: Elon Musk Responds to Twitter’s Lawsuit Over $44 Billion Deal
SUMMARY: Mr. Musk formally responded to Twitter’s attempt to force him to buy the company, arguing that there was no reason to hurry the case.

TITLE: Texas and Its Power Grid Brace for More Heat
SUMMARY: Readings of 100 or more are forecast throughout the coming week in much of the state.

TITLE: Biden Administration Retreats on Threat to Withhold Arizona Relief Funds
SUMMARY: The Treasury disbursed $2.1 billion in pandemic aid after warning it could be withheld because the state had used aid money to undercut school mask mandates.

TITLE: Fresh Data Give Fed Wiggle Room on Rates at July Meeting
SUMMARY: Inflation expectations eased, even as retail sales looked strong. That gives central bankers room to stick to their rate plan — or speed it up.

TITLE: Frontier Airlines’ Bid for Spirit Faces  Opposition From Advisory Firm
SUMMARY: Institutional Shareholder Services said a rival offer from JetBlue was more valuable, despite concerns about regulatory hurdles.

TITLE: Big Banks Send Mixed Signals on Economic Outlook
SUMMARY: In their latest financial reports, Wells Fargo showed signs of trouble but Citigroup revealed results that were better than expected.

TITLE: Voters See a Bad Economy, Even if They’re Doing OK
SUMMARY: A New York Times/Siena poll shows remarkable pessimism despite the labor market’s resilience. That could be costly for the Democrats, and the economy.

TITLE: Retail Sales Rise More Than Expected, Keeping Pressure on the Fed
SUMMARY: Central bank officials are watching closely for signs that the economy is running hot, stoking inflation, and strong spending in June could push them closer to a bigger interest rate increase.

TITLE: Average Car Payments Hit a Record High. Here’s What to Know.
SUMMARY: The average monthly payment is now about $700. But shoppers have options, including looking for less expensive smaller vehicles.

TITLE: China’s Shuddering Economic Engine
SUMMARY: Widespread lockdowns and mass quarantines in China has had far-reaching consequences for the global economy.

TITLE: Germany Hopes to Outrace a Russian Gas Cutoff and Bone Cold Winter
SUMMARY: Europe’s largest economy and key energy hub still depends on gas supplies now ensnared in conflict. Here’s how Germany is preparing and what is at stake.

TITLE: Energy Was the Only Bright Spot in the Stock Market’s Gloom
SUMMARY: But Russia’s war in Ukraine creates uncertainty about where energy funds will go in the second half of the year.

TITLE: How to Get In on the Electric Vehicle Boom
SUMMARY: One way is through investing in companies that make batteries for those vehicles and those that mine and process the minerals in the batteries.

TITLE: It’s Been a Poor Year So Far for Municipal Bonds
SUMMARY: Still, investors may have cause for optimism since yields on the bonds are rising and many state and local governments are financially flush.

TITLE: Stock Market Drop Accelerated as Recession Seemed More Likely
SUMMARY: Further losses may be on the way, even after a 20 percent drop in the first half of the year, as Wall Street continues to price in the Fed’s aggressive interest rate policy.

TITLE: Would You Pay $40 a Month to Have Strangers Watch You Work?
SUMMARY: People still working remotely are turning to virtual co-working spaces for accountability through a Zoom screen.

TITLE: China’s Economy Hits a Slump as Covid Policy Takes a Toll
SUMMARY: High unemployment, a housing market in crisis and sluggish consumer spending during lockdowns are putting pressure on Beijing in a year when officials are focused on projecting stability.

TITLE: 10-Year-Old Ohio Girl Became Flash Point in Abortion Debate
SUMMARY: The story of a 10-year-old girl in Ohio became the focus of a heated political debate that played out in the news media.

TITLE: Bank of America Is Fined $225 Million Over Pandemic Debit Cards
SUMMARY: An automated fraud filter improperly froze thousands of customers’ accounts, regulators said.
